lexUnit.name: thorny.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: causing distress, difficulty, or trouble.

sentence.text: Mr Ridley would not be drawn on the thorny issue of rail privatisation other then to say that investment was urgently needed in Britain 's rail and road links .
Unlike many top executives , he does n't believe in committing thorny issues to paper .
Such an extraordinary session of Ministers is unusual but the Americans , among others , are anxious that the thorny issue of the quota increase be resolved .
The thornier aspects continue to intrigue international legal experts .
On another thorny subject , Mr Miyazawa gently reminded Jiang that the Senkaku isles in the East China Sea , to which Peking recently reasserted its claim , belonged to Japan .
Moreover , the thorny question of additionality will have to be solved .
This is the really thorny question , but only relatively recently has it begun to receive the attention it merits .
The three still have to sort out the thorny question of who will run the centre and where it will be .
They need to struggle with the thorny issue of whose interests come first , and they must be ready to let go of some aspirations and commitments if they are to enjoy what they decide to do .
A particular thorny dilemma arises should the caring situation present demands beyond the level of endurance .

Perhaps the thorniest problems of all were those created by the aspirations of regions whose linguistic and cultural identities were actually distinct from those of Spain , or more properly of Castile .
None of these struck me as particularly penetrating answers to a thorny problem .
At the most general conceptual level of what we mean by good neighbouring , the ideas are tapping very thorny problems of the sources of social cohesion and solidarity .
Much would depend on Dulles 's mission and how he handled the thorny matters confronting him .
A clear link existed between the attempt to raise the standards of the least privileged and that most thorny of all American issues , race .
Compensation and betterment proved thorny issues and were not totally resolved until 1948 , and then only temporarily .
Then there is probably the thorniest problem of all : does the community trust in the professionalism of the police or does it insist on some greater say in its actions ?
Members , the retention of membership is a very thorny problem .
